div.head: Abstract
div.p: This paper specifies a data model for collection descriptions. The DARIAH Collection Description Data Model (DCDDM) is meant for creating descriptions of pyhsical (or analogue) AND digital collections which can be read of humans as well as machines. Concerning content and textual structure, this paper relies heavily on the Dublin Core Collections Application Profile (DCCAP).Dublin Core Collection Description Task Group, “Dublin Core Collections Application Profile” (Dublin Core Collection Description Task Group, March 9, 2007), http://dublincore.org/groups/collections/collection-application-profile/.

div.head: Introduction and design principles
div.p:
The DARIAH Collection Description Data Model (DCDDM) specifies a fixed number of classes, elements, attributes and values used for describing collections. The term “collection” is understood as it is defined by Dublin Core. A collection is “an aggregation of resources”.
Those resource can be digital objects, like digitized paintings, books, manuscripts, as well as “born-digital” objects like records of metada, database-entries, or transcripts. But those resources can also be physical objects like paintings, books, statues, stamps, coins, etc.

It is worth to mention, that the answer to the question what precisely the collection´s resources are, is not always as simple as it might look. Let´s take for instance a collection of early printed books where the book´s metada are collected and made public by an “Online Public Access Catalogue” (OPAC). Am I describing a collection of (physical) books or the matching collection of metadata (author, year of publication, number of pages, signature, …)? Or do I describe the books through describing the OPAC? The answer to this questions influences the information the collection descriptions contains. In the example of the early printed books I would most likely be more interested in the dates when the books were created as in the date of creation of the metadata records. On the other hand I may want to allow potential users of my collection to harvest the books metadata. But therefore I have to offer different information(e.g. the date when the metadata records have been created) than a description of the collection of the books.

It is also worth mentioning that a collection descriptions is based on information and that the process of gathering those information can be at least very time consuming. Therefore the level of detail of a collection description depends heavily on the descriptor´s effort. But the level of detail of a collection description also depends as well on the collection and its resource. A prestigious collection of early modern books may justify a very detailed description whereas a collection of notes and annotations made while writing a small article may be sufficiently described by providing only a small set of information.

Thirdly, the DCDDM is meant to be used a data model for applications dealing with the creation, publication and administration of collection description (e.g. the DARIAH-DE Collection Registry). Likewise the DCDDM should provide sufficient guidelines to create collection descriptions without the need of any tool or applications.
Given this broad definition of collection and the therefore very many possible varieties of collections, the DCDDM has to achieve the following objectives:

list.item: The data model should allow descriptions of digital AND physical collections.
The description should offer general descriptive information concerning the content of the collection or the collection´s items, like the
topics/subjects which are covered by the collection;
locations and regions the content of the collection could be associated with;
dates and periods the collection may be related to.
The data model should make an unambiguous identification of the described collection possible.
The data model should allow to contextualize a collection and to relationships as:
between collections to other collections like being part of another collection or containing other collections;
between collections and agents who interact with the collection like owning or curating a collection;
between collections and locations, meaning that a collection might be situated in one ore many locations;
between collections and service through which the collection´s items may be accessed or described.
Collection descriptions based on the DCDDM should encourage the exploration and usage of the described collection. Therefore the description should provide administrative information about
the possibilities of how to access the collection or the collection´s items;
possible legal restrictions concerning the possibilities to access the collection an (re)using the collection´s items.
If collections are made accessible online, technical metadata could be provided so that other services may gain access to the collection´s objects or the object´s metadata.

To avoid ambiguity the data model encourages the use of controlled vocabulary and normdata, unique identifiers, and syntax encoding schemes but to ensure human readability of the collection description the data models provides label-elements.

To facilitate mappings and transformations of already existing collection descriptions to collection descriptions based on the DCDDM, DCDDM supports several controlled vocabularies and encoding schemes (in fully awareness of the downsides of such a policy).

The data model should enable multilingual descriptions in a flexible but still practical way. This means the describing person can chooses which information in which languages he/she provides. To achieve this requirement, those elements provinding information in form of natural language and free text may be reused as often as needed to provide multilingual collection descriptions.

The data model has to be flexible enough to describe well curated collections held in museums, libraries, archives, etc. as well es less professional ones like files collected on personal hard drives while conducting a research project. To archive this requirement, the number of mandatory elements is kept as low as possible.

To achieve a high and widespread acceptance the data model should allow at least one easy to produce, read and understand serialization like a csv-table or a hierarchically as flat as possible XML-file, validated by a matching XML-Schema.

To ease interoperability and to reveal semantic closeness to well known an extensively used metadata records (e.g. Dublin Core) the names and definitions of as many classes, elements and attributes should be taken from well established ones. But to avoid any (technical) dependencies, those names, definitions and specification won´t be just referenced through simply providing quotes or links to the referenced elements but will also be written down in this document.

The DCDDM wishes to be an easy to use, but nevertheless functional and therefore widely accepted data model for collection descriptions. To acchive this goal the model has be extensively tested an evaluated in the wild. At the moment of writing this specification of the DCDDM, the model is mainly the result of a more theoretical discussion. This means that the model described in the paper has to be understood as an invitation to the interested community to use it, test it but most and for all to criticize it.

div.head: Classes and Elements
div.p: The DCDDM defines four different classes. Following the terminology defined by the DCMI Abstract Model, a “class” is understood as “A group containing members that have attributes, behaviors, relationships or semantics in common; a kind of category.”Andy Powell et al., DCMI Abstract Model, June 4, 2007, http://dublincore.org/documents/abstract-model/. The four classes refer to the real world concepts collection, agent, location, and service, and are defined through certain numbers of mandatory and optional elements. The name of classes are written in capital letters and provided with the prefix dcddm:, e.g. dcddm:COLLECTION.

A basic entity-relational model, based on the entity-relational model presented in the Dublin Core Application Profile defines the possible relationships of those four entities dcddm:COLLECTION, dcddm:AGENT, dcddm:LOCATION, and dcddm:SERVICE.
Abbildung 1: Simple entity-relational model For a more specific description of the possible relations please consult the matching class descriptions.

div.head: dcddm:COLLECTION
div.p: As stated in the DCCAP a dcddm:COLLECTION is defined as “an aggregation of items” which is “described as a group”. To describe this resource the DCDDM defines the following XX elements.
When describing a collection it is recommend to follow the order presented in this document. The name of elements are written in small caps and provided with the prefix dcddm:, e.g., dcddm:title.
If the element name is made up of a compound of two or more words, the name is written in camelcase with a small cap first letter, e.g.: dcddm:accumulationDateRange.

row.cell: A name given to the resource.

cell.p: A value string must be provided.
The use of a language attribute is recommended.
To record titles in multiple languages, use multiple statements and in each statement associate the value string with the appropriate language tag.

Where an existing name is used, the value string should preserve the original wording, order and spelling of an existing name. Punctuation need not reflect the usage of the original. Subtitles should be separated from the title by a sequence of space-colon-space, for example:
Voices from the Dust Bowl: The Charles L. Todd and Robert Sonkin Migrant Worker Collection
